headline: BOLSA ÁSIA-Índices da China fecham em alta com estímulo de Pequim e negociações comerciais em foco
News:
HONG KONG, 7 Mai (Reuters) - Os índices acionários da
China reduziram os ganhos iniciais nesta quarta-feira, uma vez
que os investidores disseram que as medidas de estímulo do banco
central chinês ofereceram poucas surpresas e persistiram dúvidas
sobre as perspectivas de um acordo comercial entre as duas
maiores economias do mundo.
    O índice CSI 300 <.CSI300> subiu 0,61%, enquanto o índice
SSEC <.SSEC>, em Xangai, avançou 0,8%, ambos perdendo ganhos
iniciais.
    O índice Hang Seng <.HSI>, de Hong Kong, fechou em alta de
0,13%, após subir mais de 2% na abertura.
    O banco central da China reduzirá a taxa de juros de
referência e injetará liquidez no sistema bancário, entre outras
medidas de estímulo, disse o presidente da instituição, Pan
Gongsheng, nesta quarta-feira, para impulsionar o crescimento
econômico e mitigar o impacto de uma guerra comercial.
    Os anúncios foram feitos poucas horas depois que autoridades
norte-americanas e chinesas disseram que o secretário do Tesouro
dos Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, e o representante comercial,
Jamieson Greer, se reunirão com a principal autoridade econômica
da China, He Lifeng, na Suíça, neste fim de semana.
    "O mercado estava esperando a taxa de compulsório e os
cortes nos juros desde o final do ano passado, portanto não há
nada de surpreendente", disse Yu Huiwu, gerente de hedge fund da
Junze Fund Management Co.
    "O contato entre a China e os EUA sobre o comércio é algo
que as pessoas esperavam que acontecesse mais cedo ou mais
tarde, mas um acordo comercial ainda não está à vista."
    . Em TÓQUIO, o índice Nikkei <.N225> recuou 0,14%, a 36.779
pontos.
    . Em HONG KONG, o índice HANG SENG <.HSI> subiu 0,13%, a
22.691 pontos.
    . Em XANGAI, o índice SSEC <.SSEC> ganhou 0,80%, a 3.342
pontos.
    . O índice CSI300 <.CSI300>, que reúne as maiores companhias
listadas em XANGAI e SHENZHEN, avançou 0,61%, a 3.831 pontos.
    . Em SEUL, o índice KOSPI <.KS11> teve valorização de 0,55%,
a 2.573 pontos.
    . Em TAIWAN, o índice TAIEX <.TWII> registrou alta de 0,12%,
a 20.546 pontos.
    . Em CINGAPURA, o índice STRAITS TIMES <.STI> valorizou-se
0,13%, a 3.865 pontos.
    . Em SYDNEY o índice S&P/ASX 200 <.AXJO> avançou 0,33%, a
8.178 pontos.
    (Por Jiaxing Li em Hong Kong e Samuel Shen em Xangai)
     ((Tradução Redação São Paulo, +55 11 5047-3075))
    REUTERS FC

headline: China Unleashes $139 Billion Stimulus Amid US Trade Showdown
News:
China Unleashes $139 Billion Stimulus Amid US Trade ShowdownMay 07, 2025

China just launched a $139 billion liquidity surge as it prepares for the first trade talks with the US since Trump's 145% tariff hike. Hours before the meeting, the People's Bank of China lowered the seven-day reverse repo rate to 1.4% and trimmed the reserve requirement ratio by half a percentage point. PBOC Governor Pan Gongsheng outlined a 10-point stimulus plan targeting sectors like tech, consumption, and elderly care — a calculated move to shore up critical economic drivers as trade tensions escalate.

Market response? Mixed. The offshore yuan erased earlier gains, and Chinese stocks cooled after an initial rally. “This isn't just easing — it's Beijing laying the groundwork for resilience, reform, and retaliation if needed,” said Charu Chanana, chief strategist at Saxo Markets. Meanwhile, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer are heading to Switzerland to meet Vice Premier He Lifeng. The question now: Will China's liquidity injection be enough to stabilize its economy amid intensifying trade pressures?

Pan emphasized that these liquidity measures are just the beginning, with more structural support aimed at shoring up critical sectors. “Resilience, reform, and retaliation,” said Chanana, underscoring Beijing's broader strategy. As the trade talks kick off, China's approach reflects a commitment to economic stability while navigating external uncertainties.

headline: BUZZ-FX options wrap - Cen-bank risks, TWD alert, EUR call, Brexit high
News:
Another day of FX consolidation within familiar ranges but implied volatility
remains supported. This highlights the simmering risks and uncertainty
surrounding U.S. tariffs and their effect on the U.S. and global economies,
exacerbated by recent TWD and other Asian currency strength. There are also the
current geopolitical tensions between Pakistan and India. 
    Despite USD/TWD recovering half of its Friday-Monday slump - related implied
volatility and TWD call over put premiums on risk reversals maintain record
highs to suggest ongoing demand for volatility and downside protection. 
    The U.S. Federal Reserve is not expected to cut rates until July, but
overnight options are not ruling out a slight increase in actual volatility from
Wednesday's announcement and press conference. Overnight GBP/USD option implied
volatility has seen the biggest increase since its expiry and also now includes
the Bank of England's expected 25bps rate cut to 4.25% on Thursday. 
    EUR/USD options remain positioned for further FX gains, with trade flows and
triggers pointing to 1.2000 and 1.2500 targets over a 6 to 12-month horizon.
Risk reversals continue to show a long-term premium for EUR calls over puts,
though slightly below mid-April and five-year highs — except for the 1-year
tenor, which holds its peak. Look out for massive EUR/USD strike expiries at the
10 a.m. New York cut on Thursday.  
    GBP/USD 1 to 3-month expiry risk reversals regain and hold their highest
premiums for topside over downside strikes since Brexit.

headline: FOREX-Dollar edges higher against yen and euro with Fed and trade talks in focus
News:
* 
      Trade negotiations, Treasury auction support the greenback
    

        * 
      Investors await Fed policy meeting outcome
    

        * 
      Euro edges down versus the dollar
    

  
 (Updates headline and first paragraph and prices throughout,
changes dateline, adds fresh analyst)
    By Chibuike Oguh and Stefano Rebaudo
       NEW YORK, May 7 (Reuters) - The U.S. dollar edged higher
against the yen and the euro on Wednesday as traders awaited the
outcome of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the
session, and uncertainty over upcoming trade negotiations still
weighed on sentiment.
    The Fed is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on
Wednesday, with investors focusing on any clues about the rate
outlook as U.S. tariffs cast uncertainty over the economy. 
    "We're still in a trading range with (the dollar) chopping
around although we're a little bit stronger today and some of
the weakness relative to the Asian currencies earlier this week
has abated a little bit," said Marvin Loh, senior global market
strategist at State Street in Boston.
    "I don't see the Fed today as an event that could break that
trend because we're still in an incredible period of uncertainty
while we're waiting for the end of this 90-day (tariff) pause
and potential deals and a broader understanding of how far the
(President Donald Trump) administration wants to push China,"
Loh added.
    U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and chief trade
negotiator Jamieson Greer will meet China's economic tsar, He
Lifeng, in Switzerland this weekend for talks that could be the
first step toward resolving a trade war that has disrupted the
global economy. 
    A well-received auction of the benchmark 10-year note on
Tuesday suggested demand for Treasuries remained intact after a
trade war shook investor confidence in U.S. assets. 
    "The unknowability of the inflationary implication of
tariffs, and the longer-term effect from a rise in inflation
expectations compel the FOMC to dissuade traders from assuming
that aggressive rate cuts are ahead," said Thierry Wizman,
global forex and rates strategist at Macquarie.
    The greenback was up 0.69% versus the yen at 143.335 <JPY=>,
breaking a three-day falling streak, with Japanese markets
reopening after a two-day holiday.
    The greenback gave up gains and was down 0.04% against the
Swiss franc <CHF=> at 0.82190. On Monday, it hit its lowest
since January 2015 of 0.8032.
    The Swiss National Bank is ready to intervene in the foreign
currency markets and cut rates even below zero to prevent
inflation falling below its price stability target, Chairman
Martin Schlegel said on Tuesday. 
    The euro <EUR=> was down 0.07% at $1.135850, after rising
0.48% the day before. 
    Forex markets took in stride the news that German
conservative leader Friedrich Merz was elected chancellor by
parliament on Tuesday in a second round of voting after an
unprecedented defeat on the first attempt. 
    France and Germany will set up a joint defense security
council that will meet regularly as part of their efforts to
boost defense investments.
    Earlier this week, a record rally in the Taiwan dollar
<TWD=TP> spread to other currencies in Asia, such as the
Singapore dollar <SGD=> and the South Korean won <KRW=>.
    The Taiwan dollar has surged against the greenback since
Trump's April 2 announcement of sweeping tariffs on trade
partners. 
    The won reached a six-month high at Wednesday's opening, but
subsequently fell 1.1%. The Chinese yuan <CNH=D3> weakened 0.07%
against the greenback to 7.216 per dollar as China announced a
long-awaited rate cut.
        
  

 (Reporting by Chibuike Oguh in New York, Stefano Rebaudo,
additional reporting by Rocky Swift; Editing by Bernadette Baum
and Ros Russell)
 ((Chibuike.Oguh@thomsonreuters.com; +332-219-1834; Reuters
Messaging: chibuike.oguh.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

headline: FOREX-Dólar sobe frente ao iene com Fed e negociações comerciais em foco
News:
Por Chibuike Oguh e Stefano Rebaudo
       NOVA YORK, 7 Mai (Reuters) - O dólar subia frente ao
iene nesta quarta-feira, com os investidores à espera da decisão
do Federal Reserve, enquanto a incerteza sobre as próximas
negociações comerciais ainda pesava sobre o sentimento.
    O Fed deve deixar a taxa de juros inalterada nesta
quarta-feira, com os investidores concentrados em quaisquer
pistas sobre as perspectivas, à medida que as tarifas dos
Estados Unidos lançam incertezas sobre a economia.
    "Ainda estamos em uma faixa de negociação com (o dólar)
oscilando, embora estejamos um pouco mais fortes hoje e parte da
fraqueza em relação às moedas asiáticas no início da semana
tenha diminuído um pouco", disse Marvin Loh, estrategista sênior
de mercado global da State Street.
    "Não vejo o Fed hoje como um evento que possa quebrar essa
tendência, porque ainda estamos em um período incrível de
incerteza, enquanto aguardamos o fim dessa pausa de 90 dias (nas
tarifas) e possíveis acordos e uma compreensão mais ampla de até
onde o governo quer pressionar a China", acrescentou Loh.
    O secretário do Tesouro, Scott Bessent, e o representante
comercial, Jamieson Greer, se reunirão com o czar econômico da
China, He Lifeng, na Suíça, neste fim de semana, para discussões
que podem ser o primeiro passo para a resolução de uma guerra
comercial que tem perturbado a economia global.
    O índice do dólar <=USD> -- que mede o desempenho da moeda
norte-americana frente a uma cesta de seis divisas -- caía
0,15%, a 99,352.
    O dólar tinha alta de 0,57% em relação ao iene <JPY=>, a
143,22. 
    O euro <EUR=> era negociado a US$1,13665, com estabilidade
no dia.
     ((Tradução Redação São Paulo, +55 11 5047-3075))
    REUTERS FC

headline: FOREX-Dollaro sale contro yen e euro, occhi su Fed e colloqui commerciali
News:
NEW YORK, 7 maggio (Reuters) - Il dollaro avanza nei confronti dello yen
e dell'euro, mentre i trader attendono l'esito della riunione di
politica monetaria di Federal Reserve e l'incertezza sui prossimi negoziati
commerciali continua a pesare sul morale degli investitori.
    ** Il dollaro/yen sale dello 0,69% a 143,24 <JPY=>, dopo tre giorni
consecutivi di perdite, con la riapertura dei mercati giapponesi dopo due giorni
di festività.
    ** Il biglietto arretra invece dello 0,3% nei confronti del franco svizzero
<CHF=> a 0,8193, dopo essere scivolato nei primi giorni della settimana ai
minimi da gennaio 2015.
    ** L'euro <EUR=> perde lo 0,01% a 1,1367 dollari, dopo un guadagno dello
0,48% ieri.
    ** I mercati valutari hanno accolto ieri con sollievo l'annuncio che il
leader conservatore tedesco Friedrich Merz è stato eletto cancelliere dal
parlamento ieri nella seconda tornata di votazioni.

headline: 更新版 1-中国汇市：人民币收跌逾百点，中美首轮会谈难有实质进展短期料延续区间震荡
News:
* 
      人民币收跌逾百点，中间价创两周新低
    

        * 
      中间价实际值与路透预测偏离仍逾310点
    

        * 
      中美经贸高层将举行会谈，市场风险情绪改善
    

        * 
      初步接触难有实质进展，短期料延续区间震荡
    

        * 
      震荡行情下客盘结汇需求或难持续
    

  
 (新增评论及收盘报价)

       路透北京5月8日 - 人民币兑美元即期<CNY=CFXS>周四收跌逾百点；中间价亦创两周新低，与路透预测偏离水平仍逾310点。市场人士指出，虽然中美经贸高层即将举行会谈，但初步接触难有实质性进展，人民币料维持区间震荡，难出现趋势性方向。
    
    他们并表示，市场风险情绪已较之前改善，但震荡行情下客盘结汇需求难以持续；为对冲中美关税战对经济的冲击，中国央行祭出宽松组合拳，后续降息操作可能会导致中美负利差拉大，美元/人民币长端掉期仍存一定调整压力。
    
    “这次中美接触安抚了市场情绪，但按照此前的节奏，可能要到第二轮、第三轮才会有点火花，估计短期还是震荡，”一中资行交易员称。
    
    该交易员并认为，人民币已度过压力最大的阶段，升值太多对中国经济利好有限，还是要以稳为主。
    
    “会谈不确定性还是很大，市场也是比较谨慎，看看能不能先把关税降下来一部分，”一外资行交易员说。
    
    
    法巴银行最新报告认为，中国央行仍倾向于美元/人民币保持稳定，虽然中国央行仍持宽松立场，但最近公布的宽松力度有限，预计近期人民币汇率将保持区间波动；未来关注中美会将关税定在什么水平以及中国后续的政策。
    
    中国官媒--人民日报周四刊发的评论员文章称，中美经贸高层会谈即将在瑞士举行，这次会谈是应美方请求举行的；中方的立场是一贯的，无论是打还是谈，中方维护自身发展利益的决心不会改变。    
    
    美联储周三维持利率不变，但指出通胀和失业率上升的风险增加，在联储努力评估特朗普关税政策的影响之际，这进一步令经济前景蒙阴。
    
    全球汇市方面，英镑周四跳涨，澳元也随之走强。[FRX/CN]纽约时报周三援引三位熟悉情况的人士的话报道称，美国总统特朗普料将于周四宣布美国与英国达成一项贸易协议。
    
    澳洲国民银行（National Australia Bank）资深外汇策略师Rodrigo Catril表示，英国的贸易协议被认为是比较容易的谈判之一，而与欧洲，特别是中国的谈判预计会更加复杂。    
    
    以下为今日在岸市场人民币兑美元<CNY=CFXS>收盘价、中间价<CNY=PBOC>，以及离岸市场人民币的主要报价：

headline: MORNING BID AMERICAS-UK eyes 'major trade deal'
News:
By Mike Dolan
       LONDON, May 8 (Reuters) - What matters in U.S. and
global markets today
By Mike Dolan, Editor-At-Large, Financial Industry and Financial
Markets
     
The spotlight hit Britain on Thursday as U.S. President Donald
Trump's 'major trade deal' announcement looks set to provide a
major relief for UK exporters, just as the Bank of England is
set to cut interest rates.
I'll get into all the market news below, and, for today's deep
dive, I'll explain why Europe may be better prepared to absorb a
deluge of global investment flows than many assume.
       
    Today's Market Minute
  
* The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on Wednesday
but said the risks of higher inflation and unemployment had
risen, further clouding the U.S. economic outlook.
     
* Trump is expected to announce a trade deal between the United
States and Britain on Thursday, the New York Times reported on
Wednesday.
     
* Ukraine is starting to consider a shift away from the U.S.
dollar, possibly linking its currency more closely to the euro
amid the splintering of global trade and its growing ties to
Europe, Central Bank Governor Andriy Pyshnyi told Reuters.
     
* Sentiment in the oil market has soured in recent weeks, but
looking at current conditions on the ground - and refiners'
profit margins - one would be forgiven for thinking that the oil
market is doing extremely well. What gives? Reuters' columnist
Ron Bousso explores this discrepancy.
    
* Concern is mounting over just how big a hit the Chinese
economy is going to take from the trade war with the United
States, but so far the commodity most at risk - iron ore - is
seemingly unaffected. Reuters' columnist Clyde Russell explains
why in his latest piece.
     
    UK eyes 'major trade deal'
  
    A British official said the U.S. and UK were working to
agree on lower tariffs for steel and autos, two sectors that
have been hit by 25% U.S. levies. In return, Britain is likely
to agree to lower its own tariffs on U.S. cars and cut a digital
sales tax that affects U.S. tech groups.
    The status of a 10% "baseline" tariff imposed by Trump on
most countries including Britain remained unclear.
    Awaiting a widely-expected quarter point UK rate cut later
today, sterling <GBP=> appeared to shrug off the anticipated
trade announcement. But the FTSE 250 <.FTMC> index of
domestically facing mid-cap stocks rose almost 1% on the news to
its highest point since late February.
    Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve chose not to change interest
rates on Wednesday, a decision that was widely expected. The
U.S. central bank flagged the high level of uncertainty ahead,
arguing that it made it challenging to make any confident
changes to policy or guidance. 
    Embattled Fed Chair Jerome Powell highlighted the risk that
trade upheaval could lift both unemployment and inflation,
creating tensions in the Fed's dual mandate on jobs and price
stability.
    "I don't think we can say which way this will shake out,"
Powell said.
    But Wall Street stocks <.SPX> ended higher nonetheless,
emboldened by hopes that the week ahead will see at least some
easing of planned U.S. tariffs amid expected deals with Britain
and others as well as weekend talks in Switzerland with China.
    U.S. stock futures <ESc1> extended those gains overnight
along with a broad advance in European and Asian bourses.
    Although the first-quarter U.S. earnings season has been
sideswiped by suspended outlooks and foggy guidance due to the
looming tariffs, estimated annual profit growth for S&P 500
companies during the first three months is running at 14% -
almost twice what it was on April 1 and above the 12% forecast
for the first quarter made at the start of the year.
    Elsewhere, US Treasury yields <US10YT=RR> were steady to a
touch higher after the Fed meeting, with $25 billion of 30-year
bonds up for auction later on Thursday.
    The dollar index <.DXY> was slightly firmer, with the euro
<EUR=> flirting with its lowest level in almost a month and
China's offshore yuan <CNH=> slipping after this week's latest
monetary easing from the People's Bank of China.
    Elsewhere, central banks in Sweden and Norway kept their
interest rates on hold.
    Regional markets were unnerved by the escalating conflict
between India and Pakistan.
    Trading was halted for an hour on Thursday at the Pakistan
Stock Exchange <.KSE> after the benchmark index plunged as much
as 6% following reports of drones being shot down in major
cities including Karachi and Lahore.
    That came a day after Indian strikes on multiple targets in
the country fanned fears of a larger military conflict between
the nuclear-armed neighbours.
    The Indian rupee <INR=>, equities <.NSEI> and bonds also
weakened in late afternoon trading there.    
            
    Europe braces for transatlantic capital reverse
  
    Europe may be better prepared to absorb a seismic shift in
global investment flows than many assume, as a number of
regulatory twists are set to bolster euro market depth.
    Trump's unilateral redrawing of world trade rules is raising
the question of whether giant U.S. capital surpluses will have
to unwind if tariff hikes succeed in squeezing America's
persistent trade deficits.
    For macro-economists, those are two sides of the same coin.
    If the administration succeeds in rebalancing the U.S.
economy, defusing dollar over-valuation and regaining the
country's manufacturing edge, that will have to involve some
shrinkage of the roughly $26 trillion U.S. Net International
Investment Position, the excess of foreign capital in U.S.
assets over U.S. investments overseas.
    During March and April, there was considerable concern that
foreign capital flight was indeed underway as U.S. stocks, bonds
and the dollar fell in tandem. The sell-off was driven by
mounting anxiety about the potential for a self-inflicted U.S.
recession or stagflation, fraying U.S. institutions and the
dollar's role as a safe haven.
    At the same time, the euro and euro stocks soared, in part
due to Germany's equally dramatic new spending and borrowing
plans that reignited hopes for longer-term growth and an
expanded pool of high-quality debt assets.
    But doubts lingered about whether Europe's smaller and
shallower capital markets could ever accommodate a repatriation
of the deluge of savings that have poured into U.S. assets over
the past decade-plus. Some $7 trillion in European savings has
flocked to Wall Street equities since 2012.
    Indeed, many reckon American markets attracted such vast
sums as much because of their unrivalled scale and liquidity as
any 'exceptional' American economic or corporate performance per
se. In turn, the euro's smaller and more fragmented markets have
raised doubts about whether the currency could ever challenge
the dollar's wide usage.
     
    NOT JUST 'NICE TO HAVE' 
    But this relative imbalance is not set in stone, especially
if Europe's markets develop apace alongside a push to meet
post-pandemic and Trump-linked challenges with a more
"high-pressure" economy and industrial policies.
    TS Lombard's Davide Oneglia argues the Trump trade shock has
underlined the urgency of last year's report from former
European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi on measures that the EU
needs to pursue to keep up with bigger economic rivals. 
    And, evidenced in part by Germany's fiscal bazooka this
year, EU leaders are now acutely aware that Draghi's demands
were not just 'nice to haves', including financial market
reforms.
    Oneglia highlights Draghi's conclusion that some 80% of the
money required for transformation of European competitiveness
will need to be financed by the private sector.
    And on that score, some progress appears to be underway.
    "EU policymakers finally appear to be getting serious about
integrating and deepening European financial markets," Oneglia
wrote this week. 
     
    BROADER, DEEPER, WIDER
    Oneglia pointed to two specifics that should help expand
long-term institutional investment across European markets. 
    First is reform of "Solvency II" regulatory rules governing
the 10 trillion euro insurance industry. This could free up
additional capital and allow a wider pool of public and private
equity to be invested in the continent. 
    The second measure is a "wildly underreported" push to
channel large European private savings into capital markets by
developing a more expansive private pension industry across the
region.
    On the latter, the European Commission this year rebranded
the old Capital Markets Union as the Savings and Investment
Union. The private pension push accompanying this is likely to
involve requirements for things like auto-enrolment in pensions
and targets for national implementation as soon as this year.
    In that spirit, Germany's new government has also made
developing private pensions a priority.
    Why this matters is that European households currently hold
about a third of their savings in cash and deposits, more than
twice the share U.S. households hold. And German savers are the
most extreme, with more than 40% of their financial wealth in
cash.
    Channeling these savings into institutional investment funds
will go a long way to deepening European markets.
    Of course, a crush of untapped savings and returning
overseas investment could flood European markets too quickly,
saddling the region with an overvalued currency - the very issue
America has fretted about for the past decade. 
    Be careful what you wish for, as the old saying goes.
"Exorbitant privilege" may not be all it's cracked up to be in
that scenario.
    Europe has to decide how to manage those investment flows as
well as what to do with the finance.
     
     
    Chart of the day 
  
    The Bank of England is expected on Thursday to nudge its
main interest rate below the Federal Reserve's key rate for the
first time since August. This will restore the U.S. rate premium
that's existed in all but a brief period over the past decade.
Markets now expect three more cuts from both central banks over
the remainder of the year. 
    However, after a fresh wobble in British government bond
yields earlier this year, 10-year gilt yields are now almost 20
basis points above U.S. Treasury equivalents, though that gap
has roughly halved in the past month.
     
    Today's events to watch
  
    * Bank of England policy decision, press conference and
monetary policy report 
    * U.S. weekly jobless claims, Q1 productivity and unit labor
costs
    * Bank of Canada governor Tiff Macklem speaks
    * US corporate earnings: ConocoPhilips, Paramount Global,
News Corp, Warner Bros Discovery, Expedia, Match, Molson Coors,
Sempra, Tapestry, Alliant, Insulet, Viatris, Microchip
Technology, Mckesson, Monster, Akamai, Solventum, TKO, Federal
Realty, Epam, Kenvue 
    * U.S. Treasury sells $25 billion 30-year bonds
     
Opinions expressed are those of the author. They do not reflect
the views of Reuters News, which, under the Trust Principles, is
committed to integrity, independence, and freedom from bias.

headline: BUZZ-FX options wrap - Pricing adjusts to changing FX climate
News:
The FX climate is changing from one of uncertainty and related
FX volatility risk to a wait-and-see situation, which is
containing spot markets and supporting risk sentiment and the
USD, at least for now.
    Wednesday's U.S. Fed policy hold appeared to be the catalyst
for deeper FX option implied volatility declines, with a sharp
retracement in USD/TWD implied volatility fuelling the slide.
Recall 1-month USD/TWD rallied from 7.0 on Friday to new record
highs at 16.0 by Monday, but sold at 11.0 in Asia Thursday. 
    Sub 3-month expiry implied volatility taking most of the
pressure in G10 options and trading lows since the initial trade
tariff announcement on April 2. 
    USD/JPY 1-month expiry implied volatility falling to 11.35
from 12.7 since Wednesday, EUR/USD 1-month from 9.5 to 8.75 and
AUD/USD 1-month from 11.7 to 10.9. GBP/USD 1-month expiry
implied volatility extended its own fall from Wednesday's 8.6
peak, through 8.0 after the Bank of England cut UK interest
rates to 4.25% as expected.  
    Risk reversals have eased marginally too but still demand a
higher premium for USD puts over calls than they did in late
March versus EUR, JPY and GBP, which shows the USD is still seen
as vulnerable against these currencies. 
    The higher USD put premium means that USD put options with
RKO triggers can still offer a significant discount to regular
vanilla USD puts.
    The premium for USD puts/CHF calls reduces the cost of
USD/CHF topside options, which could become a hot hedge if Swiss
rates go negative and/or the central bank intervenes to weaken
the CHF. 
    Range binary option are proving fruitful for those who want
to benefit from falling volatility whilst avoiding the unlimited
risks of outright short volatility positions.  
    
      
    For more click on [FXBUZ]

are his own)

headline: BUZZ-COMMENT-No Surrender Yet: Options Still Pricing USD Weakness
News:
May 9 (Reuters) - There's been a further shift in FX option pricing for
volatility and the USD outlook since Wednesday's rate hold from the U.S. Federal
Reserve, but the underlying trend to hedge the risk of more USD losses persists.
    Implied volatility gauges the risk of actual volatility - a key parameter
for an FX option premium. It's eased from new long term highs since U.S.
President Donald Trump's 90-day tariff reprieve, reflecting the mild risk
recovery and reduced volatility that isn't conducive to long option volatility
positions. 
    However, there was strong demand for USD put options as the USD suffered
after the initial April 2 tariff announcements and the bulk of these positions
remain intact as longer term hedges against more USD weakness. 
    EUR/USD hedgers bought a wealth of protection with strikes as high as 1.25
and expiries through year end. Barrier and trigger options were moved to safer
territory around 1.200 from 1.1500, with many of those having expiries in the
3-6 month zone.
    Similarly, USD/JPY options were buying a wealth of sub 140.00 strikes in
April and the latest return to 145.00 has only reduced their premiums to attract
renewed demand. 
    USD put option premiums - providing the right to sell the dollar in the
future - rose sharply through April across JPY, EUR, GBP, and CHF pairs. While
some easing has occurred recently, premiums remain elevated, especially for
longer-dated contracts.
    In summary, while options are responding to spot consolidation - driven by
improved risk sentiment and renewed trade optimism following the U.S.-UK trade
deal and hopes for progress with China - credibility concerns surrounding the
current U.S. administration continue to weigh on markets, keeping investors
cautious of renewed volatility and further USD losses.

headline: Why Asia is quietly turning its back on US dollar
News:
Why Asia is quietly turning its back on US dollarMay 09, 2025

Something unusual is happening in global currency markets, and most people aren’t paying attention. 

This week, the Taiwan dollar surged more than 5% in a single day, recording its biggest jump since 1988. 

At the same time, Asian banks, exporters, and sovereign funds are increasingly trying to bypass the US dollar in their transactions. 

It’s not a full-blown crisis, yet, but the message is clear: confidence in the US dollar is slipping, and capital is moving.

What used to be a slow drift is now turning into something larger. A big paradigm shift is underway in Asia, and the US may not be ready for it.

Is the US dollar still the world’s anchor?

For decades, the dollar has been the backbone of the global financial system.

According to a seminal 2021 paper, It is used in 88% of all currency trades. 

Roughly half of all global trade is invoiced in dollars, and the greenback still accounts for more than half of global foreign exchange reserves.

Source: Statista

But that grip is beginning to loosen. So far this year, the dollar index (DXY) is down by almost 8%, the sharpest year-to-date decline in its 20-year history. 

At the same time, most Asian currencies strengthened sharply against the dollar.

Taiwan’s dollar was the standout, gaining 5% in one day after exporters rushed to sell their dollar holdings.

Source: Bloomberg

The offshore yuan hit a six-month high.

The Hong Kong dollar tested the strong end of its trading band, triggering a $6 billion intervention by its de facto central bank.

None of these moves were isolated.

They are part of a wider trend. Asian institutions, from central banks to insurance funds, are repatriating dollar-denominated assets and hedging their exposure. 

Demand for dollar hedges has surged. Some firms are even placing restrictions on trading platforms to cope with the flood of conversion requests.

This week, Stephen Jen, a former IMF economist known for his “dollar smile” theory, estimated that Asian exporters and institutional investors hold up to $2.5 trillion in unhedged dollar positions. 

If even a fraction of that moves, it could accelerate the pressure on the dollar and fundamentally alter how global finance works.

What’s driving these currency fluctuations?

The immediate trigger is none other than President Trump’s economic agenda.

Since returning to office, he has ramped up tariff threats and pushed trade talks into a stalemate. 

US tariffs on Chinese goods currently stand at 145%, with little indication of a near-term rollback.

In return, Beijing has made it clear it expects the US to cancel what it calls “unilateral tariffs” as a condition for meaningful talks. 

Both sides are posturing, but the pressure is real.

The US economy shrank in the first quarter, marking the first contraction since 2022.

China’s manufacturing index also slipped into contraction. 

Both countries are dealing with slower demand, weaker exports, and rising capital tensions.

But the difference is that while the US still leans on the dollar’s global status, Asia is quietly adjusting its strategy.

Exporters in Taiwan, China, and Southeast Asia are no longer holding onto dollars.

They’re exchanging them faster for local currencies, betting that the dollar will weaken further. 

In some cases, they’re taking the hit on higher hedging costs just to get out.

That’s not a speculative move; it’s risk management.

And it’s being matched by action at the institutional level.

Banks across Asia are seeing increased demand for currency derivatives that bypass the dollar entirely.

That includes euro-yuan trades, rupiah-yuan swaps, and direct hedging in the Hong Kong dollar. 

A foreign bank in Indonesia is even setting up a dedicated yuan trading desk to meet local demand, according to Bloomberg.

Is this the beginning of de-dollarization?

Technically, yes. But not in the dramatic sense people often imagine.

The dollar is not being replaced overnight, and there is no credible alternative with the same depth, liquidity, or reach.

The euro’s share in global transactions has actually declined over the past two years.

And while the yuan is gaining ground, it still only accounts for about 4% of global payments, according to SWIFT data from March.

However, the trend is unmistakable. China’s Cross-Border Interbank Payment System (CIPS), its alternative to SWIFT, cleared $24 trillion in transactions last year, up 40% from 2023. 

The yuan is now being used in record volumes for China’s cross-border trades, especially with Southeast Asia and the Gulf.

Exports to those regions have grown by over 80% in the last five years, compared to much slower growth with the US and EU.

This is where the dollar’s dominance starts to erode, not from a sudden collapse, but through slow, deliberate changes in how companies and countries transact.

If the dollar becomes just one of many options, rather than the default, its role will shrink.

The cost of hedging the dollar has also increased over the past year, especially around key political events like the US election and trade policy announcements.

Traders are now pricing in more risk for holding dollars, not less.

What are the bigger risks?

The deeper risk isn’t volatility, but credibility.

The dollar’s global status rests not just on economics, but on trust. That trust is weakening. 

When the US froze Russia’s dollar reserves after the Ukraine invasion, it sent a signal that access to the dollar system could be politically conditional.

Since then, more countries have started building alternatives.

President Trump’s approach has amplified that perception.

His repeated attacks on the Federal Reserve, his unpredictable tariff policy, and his open complaints about the dollar’s strength have all made investors uneasy.

At the same time, the US is running persistent deficits, and its room for monetary easing is more limited than before.

Foreign demand for US Treasuries has already declined.

At recent auctions, the share of buyers categorized as “indirect” (which includes foreign central banks) has fallen.

If that trend continues, financing US debt could become more expensive, especially if interest rates fall and investors start looking elsewhere for return and stability.

This isn’t just about currency markets. It’s about the architecture of global capital flows.

If fewer countries are willing to hold the dollar as a reserve asset, or use it as a trade intermediary, that changes the playing field.

At the end of the day, no one expects the dollar to disappear.

But in the world of global finance, it doesn’t need to vanish to lose power. 

All it takes is for enough players to choose something else. And countries are beginning to look at their options.

The post Why Asia is quietly turning its back on US dollar appeared first on Invezz

headline: BUZZ-FX options wrap - Muted volatility hides persistent dollar risk
News:
May 9 (Reuters) - While the FX options market has responded to the
recent drop in volatility and a diminished threat of USD downside, it continues
to hold positioning, premium, and demand in place—signalling readiness for those
risks to return.
    Risk sentiment has improved, and the U.S. dollar has lifted off its recent
lows following Donald Trump's 90-day tariff reprieve through July 8. The move
was further supported by Thursday's UK-U.S. trade agreement and renewed optimism
surrounding upcoming U.S.-China trade talks.
    Implied volatility has continued to ease since Wednesday's U.S. Federal
Reserve rate hold, with many sub-3-month expiries now trading at new lows not
seen since the April 2 tariff announcement.
    However, longer-dated implied volatility has been slower to follow suit.
Even those shorter tenors, which more closely reflect spot market dynamics,
remain above their late-March levels and broader long-term lows—indicating
lingering risk perceptions.
    Demand for USD put options—which give holders the right to sell the
dollar—has picked up again as premiums softened. Yet, for longer-dated
maturities, premiums remain near recent and long-term highs. Existing USD put
positions have seen little unwinding, underscoring ongoing caution.
    In USD/TWD, market tension remains elevated. One-month implied volatility
rebounded to 14.0 on Friday after collapsing from 16.0 to 12.0 on Thursday.
Recall it had surged from 7.0 to 16.0 between last Friday and Monday, reaching
record highs. Meanwhile, 1-month risk reversals continue to reflect strong
downside protection demand, extending the record premium for USD/TWD puts over
calls to 2.9.
    Plenty of big FX option strike expiries due week of May 12-16 [nL1N3RH0BL]

headline: FOREX-Dollar set for weekly advance amid trade deal optimism
News:
* 
      Dollar gains on trade deal prospects
    

        * 
      Dollar set to notch weekly gain against yen and Swiss
franc
    

        * 
      Markets focused on US-China talks in Geneva
    

  
 (New throughout, updates headline, first paragraph, adds
analyst comment)
    By Chibuike Oguh
       NEW YORK, May 9 (Reuters) - The dollar was set for a
weekly gain against major currencies, including the Swiss franc,
yen and euro on Friday, after a U.S.-UK trade deal increased
optimism about upcoming U.S.-China talks.
    Financial markets are heading into the weekend with the
focus squarely on trade negotiations between Washington and
Beijing due to begin on Saturday in Switzerland.
    President Donald Trump had announced on Thursday a U.S.-UK
trade deal that left in place a 10% baseline tariff on British
goods, but lowered prohibitive duties on vehicle imports.
    "There's strong optimism across the market of progress in
US-China trade talks in particular and more broadly more trade
deals," said Matthew Weller, head of market research at StoneX.
    "It does seem like the Trump administration is perhaps
extending a series of olive branches to different countries and
perhaps the worst of the trade wars and tariffs is ... behind
us. That's what the market is starting to price in."
    The U.S. dollar <CHF=EBS> is on track for the fourth
straight week of gains against the Swiss franc. But it is down
0.35% to 0.82865 franc on the session.
    The euro <EUR=EBS> is set for the third straight week of
losses against the dollar. It was, however, last up 0.34% on the
day at $1.126675. 
   The U.S. currency <JPY=EBS> is on track for the third
consecutive week of gains against the Japanese yen although it
is down 0.61% to 145.025 yen on the session.
    Sterling <GBP=D3> was trading higher and was set for a
weekly gain after losing ground on Thursday following the
announcement of the U.S.-UK trade deal. It strengthened 0.42% to
$1.3302.
    Central bank decisions this week diverged: the Federal
Reserve left rates unchanged while the Bank of England cut
rates. The central banks of Sweden and Norway held them steady.
    In contrast with other G10 currencies, the dollar was lower
against several Asian currencies this week after a shock surge
in the Taiwan dollar <TWD=TP>.
    After a volatile few days, it has settled around 30 to the
dollar, more than 6% stronger than at the end of April. 
    The dollar <CNH=> weakened 0.08% to 7.236 versus the
offshore Chinese yuan, but was set for a weekly gain. The Korean
won <KRW=> strengthened 0.48% against the dollar to 1,397.98 per
dollar, also on track to finish the week higher.
    Bitcoin <BTC=> climbed back above $100,000, reflecting a
refreshed appetite for risk-taking in markets' more speculative
corners.    

 (Reporting by Chibuike Oguh and Tom Westbrook. Editing by Sam
Holmes, Toby Chopra, Mark Potter and Jane Merriman)
 ((Chibuike.Oguh@thomsonreuters.com; +332-219-1834; Reuters
Messaging: chibuike.oguh.thomsonreuters.com@reuters.net))

headline: FOREX-Dólar caminha para alta semanal em meio a otimismo com acordo comercial
News:
Por Chibuike Oguh
       NOVA YORK, 9 Mai (Reuters) - O dólar caminhava nesta
sexta-feira para registrar alta na semana em relação às
principais moedas, incluindo o franco suíço, o iene e o euro,
depois que um acordo comercial entre EUA e Reino Unido aumentou
o otimismo com as negociações entre EUA e China.
    Os mercados financeiros estão entrando no fim de semana com
o foco diretamente nas negociações comerciais entre Washington e
Pequim, que devem começar no sábado na Suíça.
    O presidente Donald Trump anunciou na quinta-feira um acordo
comercial entre EUA e Reino Unido que manteve uma tarifa básica
de 10% sobre os produtos britânicos, mas reduziu as tarifas
proibitivas sobre as importações de veículos.
    "Há um forte otimismo em todo o mercado quanto ao progresso
nas negociações comerciais entre os EUA e a China, em
particular, e, de forma mais ampla, quanto a mais acordos
comerciais", disse Matthew Weller, chefe de pesquisa de mercado
da StoneX.
    O dólar <CHF=EBS> caminha para registrar a quarta semana
consecutiva de ganhos em relação ao franco suíço, ainda que na
sessão esteja em queda de 0,35%, para 0,82865 franco.
    O euro <EUR=EBS> está se preparando para a terceira semana
consecutiva de perdas em relação ao dólar, mas no dia registra
alta de 0,34%, a US$1,126675.
    O dólar caía 0,61% frente ao iene na sessão, para 145,025, a
mas deve marcar a terceira semana de ganhos sobre a moeda
japonesa <JPY=EBS>.
    A libra esterlina <GBP=D3> era negociada em alta e estava
pronta para um ganho semanal, depois de perder terreno na
quinta-feira, após o anúncio do acordo comercial entre os EUA e
o Reino Unido. Ela subia 0,42%, para US$ 1,3302.
    As decisões dos bancos centrais nesta semana foram
divergentes: o Federal Reserve deixou as taxas inalteradas,
enquanto o Banco da Inglaterra cortou as taxas. Os bancos
centrais da Suécia e da Noruega as mantiveram estáveis.
    Em contraste com outras moedas do G10, o dólar esteve mais
baixo em relação a várias moedas asiáticas nesta semana, depois
de um aumento inesperado do dólar taiwanês <TWD=TP>.
    Após alguns dias voláteis, o dólar se estabilizou em torno
de 30, mais de 6% mais forte do que no final de abril.
    O dólar <CNH=> caia 0,08%, para 7,236, em relação ao iuan
chinês offshore, mas caminha para ganho semanal.

headline: Китайские акции выросли благодаря торговой сделке США и Китая
News:
СИНГАПУР/ШАНХАЙ, 12 мая (Рейтер) - Китайские акции
завершили торги понедельника в плюсе после того, как Соединенные
Штаты и Китай сообщили о соглашении, достигнутом на переговорах.
Снижение взаимных пошлин и некоторая разрядка напряженности дало
рынкам надежду, что торговая война между двумя крупнейшими
экономиками мира прекратится, и разрушительных  последствий
удастся избежать.
    Индекс "голубых фишек" CSI300 <.CSI300> вырос к закрытию
сессии на 1,16% до 3.890,61 пункта, а Shanghai Composite <.SSEC>
- на 0,82% до 3.369,24 пункта.
    Финансовый сектор <.CSI300FS> прибавил 1,03%, а субиндексы
потребительских товаров <.CSI000912> и недвижимости <.CSI000952>
выросли на 0,48% и 0,62% соответственно.
    Сектор здравоохранения тем временем <.CSI300HC> сбавил
0,39%.
    Подъем индекса Shanghai Composite возглавили акции Aerospace
Nanhu Electronic Information Technology <688552.SS>, China Post
Technology <688648.SS> и Sichuan Tianwei Electronic <688511.SS>.
    Гонконгский индекс Hang Seng <.HSI> подскочил на 2,98% до
23.549,46 пункта, а индекс China Enterprises <.HSCE> - на 3,01%
до 8.559,23 пункта.     
     
    Оригинал сообщения на английском языке доступен по коду:
[nL1N3RK018]

 (Бюро Рейтер в Сингапуре и Шанхае)

headline: EMERGING MARKETS-Stocks rally as US and China promise to cut tariffs, geopolitical tensions ease
News:
* 
      MSCI EM stocks index up 1.8%, FX flat
    

        * 
      Indian, Pakistani assets gain as ceasefire holds 
    

        * 
      Turkish markets gain as Kurdish PKK ends insurgency
    

        * 
      Ukraine dollar bonds rise with ceasefire talks in focus 
    

        * 
      Indian inflation data awaited
    

  
    By Johann M Cherian
       May 12 (Reuters) - Most emerging market stocks had a
positive start to the week after the U.S. and China struck a
deal to slash trade tariffs, while signs of easing geopolitical
tensions in various parts of the world further aided sentiment. 
   
    MSCI's index tracking emerging market stocks <.MSCIEF> rose
1.8% on Monday to touch levels last seen in October after the
two economic superpowers agreed a 90-day pause on measures and
said that tariffs would come down by over 100 percentage points
to a 10% baseline rate.
    "The overall scenario is not as bad as it could have been,
but we still have a fair amount of uncertainty about where these
tariffs will settle, their impact on world growth and central
bank policy," said Jane Foley, head of FX strategy at Rabobank.
    
    
    Global financial markets have been recovering from
significant volatility after Trump paused some of his tariffs on
the United States' trade partners, with MSCI's EM stocks index
up more than 15% since the worst of the rout in early April. 
    Monday's trade agreement helped Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index
<.HSI> rally 3% and Chinese stocks <.SSEC> <.CSI300> closed
about 1% higher. The offshore yuan <CNH=> appreciated 0.5%
against the dollar - its biggest one-day jump in over a week.
U.S. stock futures also extended gains following the
announcement. 
    A broader emerging markets currencies gauge <.MIEM00000CUS>
was flat as the greenback firmed 1%, reflecting renewed
confidence in the U.S. currency that had taken a beating in
April and consequently sparked a rally in Asian currencies,
particularly the Taiwanese dollar <TWD=>. Taiwan's currency
depreciated 0.7% on Monday.
    Pakistani stocks <.KSE> jumped 9.9% - their biggest one-day
gain since 1998, while hard currency bonds maturing in 2031
<US695847AT01=TE> <XS2322319638=TE> rose more than four cents on
the dollar, after the country and India reached a truce
following the worst cross-border clashes in nearly three
decades.
    A sign-off from the International Monetary Fund executive
board on Friday of a $1 billion tranche of Pakistan's $7 billion
loan programme also helped sentiment.
    Indian stock indexes <.NSEI> <.BSESN> surged about 3.5%.
April inflation data is due later in the day. 
    Turkish stocks <.XU100> were 3.2% higher, with banks
<.XUBANK> gaining 3.7% after the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK)
militant group, which has been locked in bloody conflict with
the Turkish state for more than four decades, decided to disband
and end its armed struggle, according to a report. 
    The country's hard currency bonds were slightly higher,
while the lira <TRYTOM=D3> was broadly flat.
    Traders also watched for potential Russia-Ukraine talks
after President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he was ready to meet
with Vladimir Putin in Turkey on Thursday.
    Kyiv's international bonds maturing in 2030
<XS2895056872=TE> and 2035 <XS2895057334=TE> each added more
than two cents on the dollar, while Russia's rouble <RUB=>
appreciated 2%. 
    Romania's leu <EURRON=> edged up 0.3%, recovering from its
biggest weekly decline since February 2010 after eurosceptic
presidential candidate George Simion's victory in a first-round
vote deepened a political crisis and sparked a selloff in the
currency that forced the central bank to intervene.

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Trade war truce rolls back bulk of April tariffs    https://reut.rs/4d9JuaS
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^>
 (Reporting by Johann M Cherian in Bengaluru; Editing by Kirsten
Donovan)
 ((johann.mcherian@thomsonreuters.com;))

headline: FOREX-Dollar surges after Sino-US truce improves growth outlook
News:
* 
      Dollar surges as US, China reach deal to slash tariffs
    

        * 
      Safe-haven currencies yen, Swiss franc are hit hardest
    

        * 
      US inflation, retail sales data in focus this week
    

        * 
      India-Pakistan ceasefire helps support risk sentiment
    

  
 (Updates prices)
    By Medha Singh
       May 12 (Reuters) - The dollar surged on Monday as the
United States and China struck a truce to reduce reciprocal
tariffs temporarily, easing fears of carnage from a trade war
between the world's two biggest economies.
        The U.S. will reduce extra tariffs it imposed on Chinese
imports in April to 30% from 145% and Chinese duties on U.S.
imports will fall to 10% from 125%. The de-escalation surpassed
investor expectations and follows negotiations over the weekend.
  
        The greenback's climb clobbered safe-haven currencies
the most, rising 2% to 147.835 yen <JPY=> and 1.7% to 0.845
Swiss francs <CHF=D3>. 
  
        "(U.S. President Donald) Trump has toned down his
tariffs faster than anyone thought he could. It seems that
tariffs on China will fall to manageable levels, albeit
temporarily," said Arne Petimezas, director of research at AFS
Group in Amsterdam.
  
    The dollar index <=USD> rose 1% against a basket of
currencies to hit a more than one-month high. It was still down
2.4% from Trump's April 2 announcement of sweeping tariffs as
his often chaotic rollout of policies shook confidence in U.S.
assets.
        "Now the conditions are falling into place for a deeper
adjustment and a bigger recovery of the dollar to catch up with
U.S. equities and bond yields," said Kenneth Broux, senior
strategist at Societe Generale in London.
  
        The euro tumbled 1.3% against the dollar to $1.1097
<EUR=>, on track for its steepest one-day loss this year.
Sterling shed 1% to $1.3185 <GBP=D4>.
  
        "We can see a bit more euro-dollar weakness as we're
breaking some key technical levels," Broux said.    
  
        The focus this week will also be on U.S. Consumer Price
Index (CPI) figures on Tuesday and on April retail sales due on
Thursday for indications of how the trade spat has impacted the
economy and expectations for further interest rate cuts by the
U.S. Federal Reserve. 
  
        Traders on Monday bet on fewer rate cuts by the 
    Fed
     and 
    European Central Bank
     as economic prospects improved after the Sino-US trade
deal.
  
        
  
        RISK APPETITE IMPROVES
  
    China's yuan <CNY=CFXS> hit a six-month high at 7.2001 yuan
per dollar. 
    "Although the de-escalation of the trade war benefits both
economies, the agreement... is likely to be viewed as a
particular victory for China," said ING economist Lynn Song.
        "In our view, the reduction of tariffs on China is a
sufficient enough reduction to allow for more or less a return
of normal trade." 
  
    Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions also appeared to ease over
the weekend, further supporting risk sentiment.
    India and Pakistan announced a ceasefire following four days
of fighting between the nuclear powers that had rattled markets.
And Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he was ready to
meet Russian leader Vladimir Putin in Turkey on Thursday for
direct talks. They would be the first negotiations between the
two countries since the early months of Russia's 2022 invasion.

 (Reporting by Medha Singh, Rocky Swift and Jiaxing Li,
addiotional reporting by Danilo Masoni
Editing by Shri Navaratnam, Emelia Sithole-Matarise and Gareth
Jones)
 ((medha.singh@thomsonreuters.com; within U.S. +1646 223 8780,
outside U.S. +91 80 6749 1130))

headline: BOLSA ÁSIA-Ações da China avançam e iuan sobe após acordo comercial entre EUA e China
News:
CINGAPURA/XANGAI, 12 Mai (Reuters) - As ações chinesas
avançaram e o iuan se fortaleceu nesta segunda-feira, depois que
os Estados Unidos e a China disseram ter chegado a um acordo
para reduzir as tarifas recíprocas, em uma redução substancial
de uma guerra comercial potencialmente prejudicial.
    O secretário do Tesouro dos EUA, Scott Bessent, falando após
conversações com autoridades chinesas em Genebra, disse a
repórteres que os dois lados haviam chegado ao acordo que foi
delineado em uma declaração conjunta e que as taxas recíprocas
cairão em 115 pontos percentuais.
    A medida deu aos investidores alguma confiança de que uma
guerra comercial em grande escala pode ter sido evitada. 
    O índice Hang Seng <.HSI>, de Hong Kong, subiu 2,98%,
enquanto o índice de tecnologia <.HSTECH> ganhou mais de 5%,
ambos marcando os maiores saltos em um único dia desde o início
de março.
    No fechamento, o índice de Xangai <.SSEC> teve alta de
0,82%, enquanto o índice CSI300 <.CSI300>, que reúne as maiores
companhias listadas em Xangai e Shenzhen, avançou 1,16%. 
    O iuan <CNY=CFXS> se fortaleceu até 7,2001 em relação ao
dólar, atingindo o maior valor em seis meses, enquanto sua
contraparte offshore <CNH=> subiu mais de 0,5%.
    "O resultado excede em muito as expectativas do mercado.
Anteriormente, a esperança era apenas que os dois lados pudessem
se sentar para conversar, e o mercado estava muito frágil",
disse William Xin, presidente do fundo de hedge Spring Mountain
Pu Jiang Investment Management em Xangai.
    "Agora há mais certeza. Tanto as ações chinesas quanto o
iuan estarão em alta por algum tempo."
    As reuniões de Genebra deste fim de semana foram as
primeiras interações frente a frente entre autoridades
econômicas sêniores dos EUA e da China desde que o presidente
dos EUA, Donald Trump, voltou ao poder e lançou uma ofensiva
tarifária global. 
     . Em TÓQUIO, o índice Nikkei <.N225> avançou 0,38%, a
37.644 pontos.
. Em HONG KONG, o índice HANG SENG <.HSI> subiu 2,98%, a 23.549
pontos.
. Em XANGAI, o índice SSEC <.SSEC> ganhou 0,82%, a 3.369 pontos.
. O índice CSI300 <.CSI300>, que reúne as maiores companhias
listadas em XANGAI e SHENZHEN, avançou 1,16%, a 3.890 pontos.
. Em SEUL, o índice KOSPI <.KS11> teve valorização de 1,17%, a
2.607 pontos.
. Em TAIWAN, o índice TAIEX <.TWII> registrou alta de 1,03%, a
21.129 pontos.
. Em CINGAPURA, o índice STRAITS TIMES <.STI> permaneceu
fechado.
. Em SYDNEY o índice S&P/ASX 200 <.AXJO> avançou 0,03%, a 8.233
pontos.

    
    ((Tradução Redação São Paulo))
    REUTERS CMO

headline: FOREX-Dólar sobe após trégua tarifária entre EUA e China fomentar perspectivas de crescimento
News:
Por Medha Singh
       12 Mai (Reuters) - O dólar avançava de forma acentuada
nesta segunda-feira, após os Estados Unidos e a China fecharem
uma trégua para diminuir temporariamente suas tarifas
recíprocas, reduzindo os temores de uma guerra comercial entre
as duas maiores economias do mundo.
    Os EUA reduzirão as tarifas que impuseram sobre as
importações chinesas em abril para 30%, de 145%, e as tarifas da
China sobre as importações norte-americanas cairão para 10%, de
125%. A redução superou as expectativas dos investidores e segue
as negociações do fim de semana.
    O índice do dólar <=USD> -- que mede o desempenho da moeda
norte-americana frente a uma cesta de seis divisas -- subia
1,29%, a 101,890.
    O dólar tinha alta de 2,17% em relação ao iene <JPY=>, a
148,5. 
    O euro <EUR=> era negociado a US$1,107775, em queda de 1,51%
no dia.
    "(O presidente dos EUA, Donald) Trump reduziu suas tarifas
mais rápido do que se imaginava. Parece que as tarifas sobre a
China cairão para níveis administráveis, ainda que
temporariamente", disse Arne Petimezas, diretor de pesquisa do
AFS Group.
    Ainda assim, o dólar recuou 2,4% desde o anúncio de tarifas
abrangentes feito por Trump em 2 de abril, uma vez que sua
implementação caótica de políticas abalou a confiança nos ativos
dos EUA.
    "Agora, as condições estão se encaixando para um ajuste mais
profundo e uma recuperação maior do dólar para acompanhar as
ações e os rendimentos dos títulos dos EUA", disse Kenneth
Broux, estrategista sênior do Société Générale.
    O foco desta semana também estará nos números de inflação ao
consumidor dos EUA, na terça-feira, e nas vendas no varejo de
abril, na quinta-feira, para obter indicações de como a disputa
comercial afetou a economia e as expectativas de novos cortes na
taxa de juros pelo Federal Reserve. 
     ((Tradução Redação São Paulo, +55 11 5047-3075))
    REUTERS FC

headline: EMERGING MARKETS-Акции ЕМ растут на фоне сделки США и Китая, снижения геополитической напряженности
News:
12 мая (Рейтер) - Большинство фондовых индексов
развивающихся рынков начали неделю позитивно благодаря улучшению
рыночного настроя после того, как Пекин и Вашингтон достигли
соглашения о взаимном снижении пошлин.
    Индекс акций развивающихся рынков MSCI к 13:19 МСК <.MSCIEF>
поднялся на 1,83%, коснувшись максимума с октября 2024 года.
    "Общая ситуация не настолько плоха, как могла быть, но все
еще сохраняется значительная неопределенность по поводу того, на
каком уровне будут в результате установлены пошлины, и какое
влияние они окажут на мировой экономический рост и политику
центральных банков", - сказала Джейн Фоули из Rabobank.

    Благодаря торговой сделке двух крупнейших экономик мира
китайские акции завершили торги понедельника в плюсе <.HSI>
<.SSEC> <.CSI300>, а юань <CNH=> достиг максимума шести месяцев.
    Индекс валют развивающихся рынков MSCI <.MIEM00000CUS> тем
временем почти не изменился на фоне укрепления доллара,
отразившего восстановление доверия к американской валюте.
    Пакистанский фондовый индекс <.KSE> подскочил на 9,9%,
показав максимальный однодневный рост с 1998 года, а валютные
облигации со сроком погашения в 2031 году <US695847AT01=TE>
<XS2322319638=TE> подорожали более чем на четыре цента за доллар
на фоне новостей о том, что Нью-Дели и Исламабад заключили
перемирие после четырех дней боевых действий.
    Индийская рупия <INR=> укрепилась на 0,65% до 84,83 за
доллар, а основные индексы Бомбейской фондовой биржи Nifty 50
<.NSEI> и BSE <.BSESN> поднялись на 3,82% и 3,74%
соответственно.
    Акции в Стамбуле прибавили 3% после сообщения
информационного агентства Firat о том, что Рабочая партия
Курдистана приняла решение о самороспуске и прекращении
вооруженной борьбы.
     
    Оригинал сообщения на английском языке доступен по коду:
[nL4N3RK0QF]

headline: FOREX-Dólar sobe após tréguas sino-norte-americanas melhorarem perspectivas de crescimento
News:
12 Mai (Reuters) - O dólar apreciou, esta segunda-feira,
numa altura em que Estados Unidos e China chegaram a uma trégua
para reduzir temporariamente as tarifas recíprocas, atenuando os
receios de uma guerra comercial entre as duas maiores economias
do mundo.
    Os Estados Unidos reduzirão as tarifas adicionais que
impuseram às importações chinesas em Abril para 30%, de 145%, e
os direitos chineses sobre as importações norte-americanas
cairão para 10%, de 125%. O desanuviamento ultrapassou as
expectativas dos investidores e surge na sequência das
negociações do fim-de-semana.
    A subida do dólar afectou mais as moedas portos-seguros,
subindo 2% para os 147,835 ienes <JPY=> e 1,7% para 0,845
francos suíços <CHF=D3>.
    O índice do dólar <=USD> subiu 1% contra um cabaz de moedas,
atingindo um máximo de mais de um mês. Ainda estava 2,4% abaixo
do anúncio de tarifas abrangentes de Trump a 2 de Abril, já que
o seu lançamento frequentemente caótico de políticas abalou a
confiança nos activos norte-americanos.
    O euro caiu 1,3% face ao dólar para os 1,1097 dólares
<EUR=>, a caminho de sua maior perda num dia este ano. A libra
caiu 1% para os 1,3185 dólares <GBP=D4>.
    Esta semana, as atenções estarão também centradas nos
números do Índice de Preços no Consumidor (IPC) dos Estados
Unidos, na terça-feira, e nas vendas a retalho de Abril, na
quinta-feira, para indicações sobre o impacto da disputa
comercial na economia e as expectativas de novos cortes nas
taxas de juro pela Reserva Federal dos Estados Unidos.
    Esta segunda-feira, os investidores apostaram em menos
cortes nas taxas da Reserva Federal e do Banco Central Europeu,
já que as perspectivas económicas melhoraram após o acordo
comercial sino-norte-americano.
    
Texto integral em inglês: [nL1N3RK076]

 (Por Medha Singh; Tradução para português por Tiago Brandão,
Gdansk Newsroom)
 ((gdansk.newsroom@thomsonreuters.com ; +48 58 769 66 00))

headline: FOREX-El dólar sube luego de que tregua entre China y EEUU mejora las perspectivas de crecimiento
News:
Por Medha Singh
       12 mayo (Reuters) - El dólar subía el lunes después de
que Estados Unidos y China alcanzaran una tregua para reducir
temporalmente los aranceles recíprocos, aliviando los temores de
una guerra comercial entre las dos mayores economías del mundo.
    * Estados Unidos reducirá los aranceles adicionales que
impuso a las importaciones chinas en abril al 30% desde el 145%
y los aranceles chinos a las importaciones estadounidenses
caerán al 10% desde el 125%. La rebaja superó las expectativas
de los inversores y se produce tras las negociaciones del fin de
semana.
    * La escalada del billete verde afectaba sobre todo a las
divisas refugio. El dólar subía un 2% frente a la moneda
japonesa, a 147,835 yenes <JPY=> y un 1,7% ante la divisa suiza
a 0,845 francos <CHF=D3>.
    * El índice dólar <=USD> subía un 1% frente a una cesta de
seis divisas y alcanzaba un máximo de más de un mes. Aún suma
una pérdida de un 2,4% desde el anuncio de Trump del 2 de abril
de aranceles radicales, ya que su despliegue a menudo caótico de
las políticas sacudió la confianza en los activos
estadounidenses.
    * El euro <EUR=> caía un 1,3% frente al dólar, a 1,1097
dólares, camino de registrar su mayor pérdida en un día de este
año. La libra <GBP=D4> perdía un 1%, a 1,3185 dólares.
    * Esta semana, la atención se centrará también en las cifras
del índice de precios al consumo (IPC) de Estados Unidos el
martes, y en las ventas minoristas de abril, que se publicarán
el jueves, para conocer el impacto del conflicto comercial en la
economía y las expectativas de nuevos recortes de las tasas de
interés por parte de la Reserva Federal estadounidense.
    * El lunes, los operadores apostaron por menos recortes de
tipos por parte de la Fed y el Banco Central Europeo, ya que las
perspectivas económicas mejoraron tras el acuerdo comercial
entre China y Estados Unidos.
    * El yuan chino <CNY=CFXS> alcanzó un máximo de seis meses,
situándose en 7,2001 unidades por dólar.
    * En tanto, las tensiones geopolíticas también parecieron
aliviarse durante el fin de semana, apoyando aún más el
sentimiento de riesgo.
    * India y Pakistán anunciaron un alto el fuego tras cuatro
días de enfrentamientos entre las potencias nucleares que habían
sacudido los mercados.
    * El presidente ucraniano, Volodímir Zelenski, se declaró
dispuesto a reunirse con el líder ruso, Vladimir Putin, el
jueves en Turquía para mantener conversaciones directas. Serían
las primeras negociaciones entre ambos países desde los primeros
meses de la invasión rusa de 2022.

 (Reporte de Medha Singh, Rocky Swift y Jiaxing Li, reporte
adicional de Danilo Masoni; Editado en Español por Ricardo
Figueroa)
 ((medha.singh@thomsonreuters.com; within U.S. +1646 223 8780,
outside U.S. +91 80 6749 1130; Mesa de edición en español;
santiago.desk@thomsonreuters.com))

headline: FOREX-Dollar surges after China-US truce improves growth outlook
News:
* 
      Dollar surges as US, China reach deal to slash tariffs
    

        * 
      Safe-haven currencies yen, Swiss franc are hit hardest
    

        * 
      US inflation, retail sales data in focus this week
    

        * 
      India-Pakistan ceasefire helps support risk sentiment
    

  
 (Updates prices)
    By Medha Singh
       May 12 (Reuters) - The dollar surged on Monday as the
United States and China struck a truce to reduce reciprocal
tariffs temporarily, easing fears of carnage from a trade war
between the world's two biggest economies.
        The U.S. will reduce extra tariffs it imposed on Chinese
imports in April to 30% from 145% and Chinese duties on U.S.
imports will fall to 10% from 125%. The de-escalation surpassed
investor expectations and followed negotiations over the
weekend.
  
        The greenback's climb clobbered safe-haven currencies
the most, rising 1.9% to 148.16 yen <JPY=> and 1.5% to 0.8443
Swiss francs <CHF=D3>. 
  
        "(U.S. President Donald) Trump has toned down his
tariffs faster than anyone thought he could. It seems that
tariffs on China will fall to manageable levels, albeit
temporarily," said Arne Petimezas, director of research at AFS
Group in Amsterdam.
  
    The dollar <=USD> rose 1.1% against a basket of currencies
to hit a more than one-month high. It was still down 2.3% from
Trump's April 2 announcement of sweeping tariffs as his often
chaotic rollout of policies shook confidence in U.S. assets.
        "Now the conditions are falling into place for a deeper
adjustment and a bigger recovery of the dollar to catch up with
U.S. equities and bond yields," said Kenneth Broux, senior
strategist at Societe Generale in London.
  
        The euro tumbled 1.3% against the dollar to $1.111
<EUR=>, on track for its steepest one-day loss this year.
Sterling shed 1% to $1.318 <GBP=D4>.
  
        "We can see a bit more euro-dollar weakness as we're
breaking some key technical levels," Broux said.    
  
        The focus this week will also be on U.S. Consumer Price
Index (CPI) figures on Tuesday and on April retail sales due on
Thursday for indications of how the trade spat has impacted the
economy and expectations for further interest rate cuts by the
U.S. Federal Reserve. 
  
        Traders on Monday bet on fewer rate cuts by the 
    Fed
     and 
    European Central Bank
     as economic prospects improved after the Sino-US trade
deal.
  
        
  
        RISK APPETITE IMPROVES
  
        The New Zealand and Australian dollars, widely seen as
proxies for risk assets, advanced 0.5% to $0.58790 <NZD=D4> and
added 0.3% at $0.639 <AUD=D4>, respectively.
  
    China's yuan <CNY=CFXS> hit a six-month high at 7.2001 yuan
per dollar. 
    "Although the de-escalation of the trade war benefits both
economies, the agreement... is likely to be viewed as a
particular victory for China," ING economist Lynn Song said.
        "The reduction of tariffs on China is a sufficient
enough reduction to allow for more or less a return of normal
trade." 
  
    Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions also appeared to ease over
the weekend, further supporting risk sentiment.
    India and Pakistan announced a ceasefire following four days
of fighting between the nuclear powers which had rattled
markets. 
    Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he was ready to
meet Russian leader Vladimir Putin in Turkey on Thursday for
direct talks. That would be the first negotiations between the
two countries since the early months of Russia's 2022 invasion.

    <^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
How markets react with US-China tariff pause    https://reut.rs/3SwivwF
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^>
 (Reporting by Medha Singh, Rocky Swift and Jiaxing Li,
addiotional reporting by Danilo Masoni
Editing by Shri Navaratnam, Emelia Sithole-Matarise, Gareth
Jones and Ed Osmond)
 ((medha.singh@thomsonreuters.com; within U.S. +1646 223 8780,
outside U.S. +91 80 6749 1130))
